```java
public class EndlessIterable implements Iterable<String> {
    static class EndlessIterator implements Iterator<String> {
        private long startTime;
        private long maxTime;

        public EndlessIterator(long maxTime) {
            this.startTime = System.currentTimeMillis();
            this.maxTime = maxTime;
        }

        public boolean hasNext() {
            return System.currentTimeMillis() - startTime < maxTime;
        }

        public String next() {
            if (System.currentTimeMillis() - startTime >= maxTime) {
                throw new NoSuchElementException("Time limit exceeded");
            }
            try {
                Thread.sleep(2000);
            } catch (InterruptedException e) {
                Thread.currentThread().interrupt();
            }
            return "" + System.currentTimeMillis();
        }
    }

    private long maxTime;

    public EndlessIterable(long maxTime) {
        this.maxTime = maxTime;
    }

    public Iterator<String> iterator() {
        return new EndlessIterator(maxTime);
    }
}

// Test code
EndlessIterable iterable = new EndlessIterable(20000);
try {
    for (String s : iterable) {
        System.out.println(s);
    }
} catch (NoSuchElementException e) {
    System.out.println("Time limit exceeded");
}
System.out.println("done");
```
<<<explanation>>>: In this code, we modify the `hasNext()` method of the `EndlessIterator` to check if the current time minus the start time is less than the maximum time allowed for iteration. If it is, `hasNext()` returns true, otherwise it returns false. This will effectively stop the iteration after the specified time. In the `next()` method, we throw a `NoSuchElementException` if the time limit is exceeded. This exception will be caught in the test code, and "Time limit exceeded" will be printed. After the catch block, "done" will be printed, indicating the end of the code.
